The loan would be repaid over a 10-year period. *In early October 2007, MEA announced a modified livery for its fleet as well as an increase of its A320 order from four to six aircraft. *In November 2009, MEA placed an order for an [[Airbus A319]] with delivery expected late 2010 to early 2011, but this was later converted to another A320 order. *In 2012, MEA confirmed an order for five [[Airbus A320neo family|Airbus A320neos]] (later converted to A321neos) and five [[Airbus A320neo family|Airbus A321neos]] along with eight options. All aircraft will be equipped with Wi-Fi, with the first delivery expected in 2019. *MEA received its eleventh Airbus A320-200 on 2 October 2013, painted in a "Skyteam" livery. *On January 5 2016, the MEA Group took delivery of an Embraer Legacy 500 [[business jet]], to be operated by Cedar Executive, a Middle East Airlines subsidiary.{{cite press release|url=https://www.mea.com.lb/english/about-us/news-and-press-releases/mea-newly-established-subsidiary-cedar-executive-took-delivery-of-its-first-private-jet#sthash.g91GR8cX.dpuf |title=MEA newly established subsidiary Cedar Executive took delivery of its first Private Jet |publisher=Middle East Airlines |date=5 January 2016 |access-date=25 May 2016}} *On December 28 2016, the airline revealed the purchase of an additional Airbus A330-200 aircraft."SGBL finances MEA Airbus purchase." The aircraft ordered could be either the [[Airbus A330neo|Airbus A330-900neo]] or the [[Boeing 787 Dreamliner|Boeing 787-9 Dreamliner]]. ==Frequent-flyer program== In 2011, Middle East Airlines changed its frequent-flyer program to a 4-tier program- Blue Cedar, Silver Cedar, Golden Cedar, and President's Club, respectively- in preparation for joining the [[SkyTeam]] airline alliance. Silver Cedar, Golden Cedar, and President's Club members gain numerous benefits such as access to the Cedar Lounge at [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]], as well as outstation lounges at all MEA destinations. Golden Cedar and President's Club also include guaranteed seat reservation in economy as well as other extra benefits.[http://www.mea.com.lb/English/CedarMiles/EarningYourMiles/Pages/TopTiersPrivileges.aspx Earning Frequent Flyer Miles] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102120426/http://www.mea.com.lb/English/CedarMiles/EarningYourMiles/Pages/TopTiersPrivileges.aspx |date=2012-01-02 }} Cedar Miles can be earned and redeemed on all MEA flights and on all flights operated by [[Air France]], [[KLM]], and [[Qatar Airways]], as well as codeshare partners on certain routes. Cedar Miles can also be earned during stays at all [[Rotana Hotels]] and all [[The Hertz Corporation|Hertz]] car rentals worldwide.[http://www.mea.com.lb/English/CedarMiles/Partners/Pages/HowToEarnMilesWithOurPartners.aspx Frequent Flyer Partners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111231205128/http://www.mea.com.lb/English/CedarMiles/Partners/Pages/HowToEarnMilesWithOurPartners.aspx |date=2011-12-31 }} ==Subsidiaries== MEA owns the following subsidiaries, which are operated independently ''' *'''Cedar Executive''' ::Founded in January 2016, Cedar Executive is a private jet service based at [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]] which operates business flights across [[Europe]] and the [[Middle East]]. Clients stay in a luxury lounge on arrival to the airport and prior to boarding, and are then transported to the private jet by a chauffeured car. The aircraft used are two [[Embraer Legacy 500]].Sarsfield, Kate. "MEBAA: Embraer sells second Legacy 500 to Cedar Executive." Flightglobal.com. N.p., n.d. Web. . *'''Middle East Airlines Ground Handling (MEAG)''' ::Founded in 1999, MEAG is the main ground handling agent at [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]] handling nearly 80% of all traffic. MEAG also operates a [[fixed-base operator]] called ''Cedar Jet Center'' at the General Aviation Terminal. *'''Middle East Airports Services (MEAS)''' ::Founded in 1998, MEAS is responsible for the operation and maintenance of [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]] conducting many services ranging from cleaning the terminal to [[Airfield rubber removal|de-rubberising]] the runways. *'''Mideast Aircraft Services Company (MASCO)''' ::Founded in 1955, MASCO is the only fully fledged aircraft maintenance, repair, and overhaul provider at [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]]. MASCO is a part 145 [[European Aviation Safety Agency|EASA]]-approved MRO with full airframe check capabilities on the [[Airbus]] [[Airbus A300|A300]], [[Airbus A310|A310]], [[Airbus A320 family|A320]], and [[Airbus A330|A330]] family aircraft. In addition, MASCO is certified to performing painting on all types of aircraft. * In addition to the four wholly owned subsidiaries above, MEA owns 77.5% of the '''Lebanese Beirut Airport Catering Company (LBACC)''' which is the only catering provider at [[Beirut Rafic Hariri International Airport]] with capacity of 20,000 meals/day ==Accidents and incidents== [[File:Destroyed MEA aircraft 1982.jpg|thumb|An MEA aircraft was destroyed during a confrontation between the Israelis and the [[Palestine Liberation Organization]] in 1982]] *On 24 July 1950, an Air Liban [[Douglas DC-3]], registration LR-AAN was shot at by an Israeli Spitfire fighter; the DC-3 landed safely at Beirut Airport, but 3 passengers (of 28 on board) were killed in the attack.{{ASN accident|title= LR-AAN|id= 19500724-0|accessdate= 2015-1-7}} *On 6 January 1952, Air Liban [[SNCASE Languedoc]] OD-ABU crashed on take-off from [[Beirut Airport]], and was consequently destroyed by fire. All nine passengers and crew on board survived. The aircraft was operating a scheduled international passenger flight from Beirut to [[Kuwait Airport]], Kuwait.{{cite web |url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19540106-0 |title=OD-ABU Accident description |website=Aviation Safety Network |publisher=Flight Safety Foundation |accessdate=28 February 2014}} *On 29 September 1958, Middle East Airlines [[Avro York]] OD-ADB disappeared over the Mediterranean Sea with five on board.{{ASN accident|title= OD-ADB|id= 19580929-0|accessdate= 2016-7-1}} *On 1 February 1963, [[1963 Ankara mid-air collision|Flight 265]], a [[Vickers Viscount|Vickers Viscount 754D]] registered OD-ADE, was involved in a mid-air collision with [[Turkish Air Force]] [[Douglas C-47 Skytrain|C-47]] ''CBK28''. Both aircraft crashed in [[Ankara]], killing all 14 on board the Viscount, all 3 on board the C-47 and a further 87 people on the ground.{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19630201-0 |title=Accident description |website=Aviation Safety Network |publisher=Flight Safety Foundation |accessdate=6 October 2009}} *On 17 April 1964, Flight 444, operated by [[Sud Aviation Caravelle|Sud Caravelle III]] OD-AEM struck the sea near [[Dhahran]], Saudi Arabia, killing all 49 on board; the cause of the accident was not determined."[https://www.webcitation.org/6O0fIX8IK?url=http://web.archive.org/web/20001018233800/http://www.aviation-safety.net/reports/640417-0.htm Middle East Airlines SE 210 Caravelle III OD-AEM accident at sea 10 NM SSE of Dhahran Airport, Saudi Arabia on 17 April 1964.]" () Committee of Accident Investigation convened by the Superintendent Director General of Civil Aviation, Saudi Arabia. July 1964. Prepared by [[Aviation Safety Network]]. *On 21 April 1964, Middle East Airlines Vickers Viscount 754D OD-ACX was damaged beyond economic repair at [[El Arish International Airport|El Arish]], Egypt after the taxiway it was taxiing on collapsed.{{cite web|url=http://aviation-safety.net/database/record.php?id=19640421-0 |title=Accident description |website=Aviation Safety Network |publisher=Flight Safety Foundation |accessdate=6 October 2009}} *On 28 December 1968, seven {{efn|Vickers Viscount OD-ACT; Sud Caravelles OD-AEE and OD-AEF; de Havilland Comets OD-ADQ, OD-ADR and OD-ADS; Boeing 707 OD-AFC; and a Ghana Airways Vickers VC10 (9G-ABP) operating for MEA}} MEA aircraft were destroyed in a raid by [[Israel]]i Commandos at [[Beirut International Airport]]. {{Infobox person |name = Morris Llewellyn Cooke |image = Morris Llewellyn Cooke.jpg |caption = Morris Llewellyn Cooke, 1911 |birth_name = |birth_date = {{Birth date|1872|5|11}} |birth_place = [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]], U.S. |death_date = {{death date and age|1960|3|5|1872|5|11}} |death_cause = |resting_place = |resting_place_coordinates = |residence = |nationality = American |other_names = |known_for = [[Rural Electrification]] |education = [[Lehigh University]] |employer = |occupation = [[Engineer]] |awards = |home_town = |party = |boards = |religion = |spouse = |relatives = |signature = }} '''Morris Llewellyn Cooke''' (May 11, 1872 – March 5, 1960) was an American [[engineer]], best known for his work on [[Scientific Management]]<ref>[[Wrege, Charles D.]], and Anne Marie Stotka. "Cooke creates a classic: the story behind FW Taylor's principles of scientific management." ''Academy of Management Review'' 3.4 (1978): 736-749.</ref> and [[Rural Electrification]].<ref>Cooke, Morris Llewellyn. "The Early Days of the Rural Electrification Idea: 1914-1936." ''The American Political Science Review'' 42.3 (1948): 431-447.</ref><ref>Nye, David. ''Electrifying America: Social meanings of a new technology''. MIT press, 1990.</ref>
== Biography == Born in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]] as one of eight children to William Harvey Cooke and Elizabeth Richmond Marsden, Cooke attended [[Lehigh University]] in 1895 and obtained his degree in [[mechanical engineering]]. After Cooke had completed college and earned his degree from Lehigh University in mechanical engineering, he went into the work force to become a machinist. In 1900 he married Eleanor Bushnell Davis, a granddaughter of the industrialist [[Daniel Bushnell]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The New Dealers: Power Politics in the Age of Roosevelt|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=o2pOlssB9fUC&pg=PT326&lpg=PT326&dq=eleanor+bushnell+davis+cooke&source=bl&ots=ZXGHHwj8OG&sig=4EWvv18AHkv27C-aKTvF545yJSM&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiOlaTmi83bAhVDi1kKHZSiCc8Q6AEILzAC#v=onepage&q=eleanor%20bushnell%20davis%20cooke&f=false |accessdate=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Cooke served as the director of the Rural Electrification Administration from May 1935 through March 1937. In March 1937, Cooke resigned and was succeeded by [[John Carmody]]. In 1940 Cooke became a technical consultant for the Office of Production Management, where he led an American technical mission to Brazil. In 1943 headed the [[National War Labor Board (1942–1945)|War Labor Board]] panel to mediate a coal miners' strike. In the year 1946-1947 he was a member of a committee "jump, jump, jump" to survey the patent system. In 1950 President [[Harry S. Truman]] appointed Cooke chairman of the [[Water Resources Policy Commission]]
Cooke was recognized for his work on obtaining inexpensive electricity for residential use, facilitating better labor-management relations, and the conservation of land and water resources. As he wrote in 1913, "We shall never fully realize . . . the dreams of democracy until the principles of scientific management have permeated every nook and cranny of the working world."<ref>''[[Business Week]]'', 18 Apr. 1964, p. 132</ref>
== Work ==
=== Scientific management === In 1903 Cooke met a [[mechanical engineer]] that would later become very influential in Cooke's work, [[Frederick Winslow Taylor|Frederick W. Taylor]]. Taylor chose four men to implement his theories of scientific management in the work force; Cooke was one of these men. It was at this time that Cooke and Taylor developed a professional relationship and Taylor's principles influenced Cooke to believe that "the application of scientific management principles to industry would benefit all of society." This belief later led to the creation of Cooke's own scientific consultant firm in 1905.
In 1911, Cooke was appointed director of the [[Public works|Department of Public Works]] by Philadelphia's reform mayor, [[Rudolph Blankenburg]]. It was here that Cooke began to implement Taylor's principles of Scientific Management in order to change what he considered inefficient management practices in several departments. This change saved taxpayers thousands of dollars. This work was later reflected during World War II when he served on several boards. While serving on these boards Cooke was able to improve the storage of military goods. He also reorganized the Quartermaster Corps, and provided more electrical service to shipyards.
Between 1923 and 1925, Cooke administered a survey under Pennsylvania governor [[Gifford Pinchot]]. This survey "emphasized public support for rural electrification and state-directed reorganization of the electric industry."
=== Rural electrification === Morris Cooke had been interested in, and began working toward, the idea of [[rural electrification]] beginning in the 1920s. Cooke had been a progressive Republican prior to 1930, but following the election of [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], Cooke shifted his support and became a liberal Democrat. Morris Cooke was selected for several committees by President Roosevelt; these included: * the Upstream Engineering Conference, * the Great Plain Drought Area Committee, and * the Mississippi Valley Committee. However, Cooke was most influential in his appointment as the director for the [[Rural Electrification Administration]]. This agency had been newly organized by the Roosevelt Administration, and it was set up to finance the construction of several power distribution systems that lay within rural areas. Many of these rural areas had no available electricity, so it became Cooke's duty to work towards rural electrification.
== Selected publications == * ''[https://archive.org/details/academicindustri05cookuoft Academic and Industrial Efficiency]'' (1910) * ''[https://archive.org/details/jstor-1946060 Scientific Management of the Public Business]''(1915) * ''[https://archive.org/details/ourcitiesawaken00cookgoog Our Cities Awake]'' (1918) * ''Brazil on the March'' (1944) * ''Organized Labor and Production'' (1940) * ''Giant Power: Large Scale Electrical Development as a Social Factor'' (1925) * ''Modern Manufacturing: A Partnership of Idealism and Common Sense'' (1919)
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * ''The Life and Times of a Happy Liberal: A Biography of Morris Llewellyn Cooke'' (1954), Kenneth E. Trombley * ''Morris Llewellyn Cooke, Progressive Engineer'' (1983), Jean Christie

{{Infobox company | name = Octagon Computer Superstore | logo = Octagon Computer Superstore logo.jpg | logo_size = 230px | image = Octagon KCC Mall De Zamboanga.jpg | image_caption = Octagon Computer Superstore branch at [[KCC Mall de Zamboanga]] | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | founder = | area_served = [[Philippines]] | key_people = | industry = [[Retail]] | genre = | products = [[Consumer electronics]] | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = 1000<ref>http://www.octagon.com.ph/en/content/4-about-us</ref> | parent = | divisions = | subsid = MicroValley & Gadget King | foundation = 1982 | location_city = 747 Romualdez Cor. Zobel St. Ermita, [[Manila]] | location_country = [[Philippines]]<ref name="pbd.ph">http://pbd.ph/directory/makati-city/electronics-appliances-gadgets/octagon-computer-superstore</ref> | location = | origins = | slogan = | homepage = [http://www.octagon.com.ph/ Octagon Official Website] }} '''Octagon Computer Superstore''' is a computer retail store in the [[Philippines]]. It has 150 branches nationwide along with their subsidiary, Micro Valley Computer Center<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.octagon.com.ph/en/content/35-octagon-branch|title=Octagon Branch - Octagon|website=www.octagon.com.ph|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref> with headquarters at 747 Romualdez Street, corner Zobel Street, [[Ermita]], [[Manila]].<ref name="pbd.ph">http://pbd.ph/directory/makati-city/electronics-appliances-gadgets/octagon-computer-superstore</ref> The store offers [[information technology]] products, mainly computers and components, laptops, [[smartphone]]s and [[Tablet computer|tablet]]s and the like.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://kccmalls.com/mall-branches/kcc-mall-of-gensan/misc-pages/octagon/|title=KCC Malls - Octagon|last=acceleratedesk.com|website=kccmalls.com|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
== History == Octagon Computer Superstore started in 1982 as an IT products retailer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://davaoportal.com/ads/octagon-computer-superstore-davao/|title=Octagon Computer Superstore Branches in Davao City {{!}} Davao Portal|website=davaoportal.com|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> They mainly sell computer sets, accessories and components.<ref name=":2" /> It then grew from a being an IT products retailer with a lone store in Manila to a chain of computer retail stores with branches nationwide.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.octagon.com.ph/en/content/4-about-us|title=About us - Octagon|website=www.octagon.com.ph|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.libre247.com/store/viewstore/Octagon-Computer-Superstore|title=Discounts from Octagon Computer Superstore|website=www.libre247.com|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
From 1990s to 2010, Octagon became the country's reselling partner to various global technological brands such as [[Acer Inc.|Acer]], [[Hewlett-Packard|Hewett-Packard]], [[Logitech]], and [[Seagate Technology|Seagate]]. With high sales from Octagon within that year, the company was given citations such as the Acer's Excellent Major Account Development Award in 1995 and Cisco's Retail Store of the Year in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.octagon.com.ph/en/content/8-awards|title=Awards - Octagon|website=www.octagon.com.ph|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
Upon their development to attain nationwide reach, Octagon Computer Superstore opened their subsidiary store, Micro Valley Computer Center, with several branches in [[Cabanatuan]], [[Davao City|Davao]], [[Dumaguete]] and [[Manila]]. Micro Valley are focused more on computer parts and accessories, and also offers extended computer repair service. Meanwhile, from IT products, Octagon expanded their sales to computer accessories, gadgets, android phones and tablets, and digital printers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.octagon.com.ph/en/content/7-products|title=Products - Octagon|website=www.octagon.com.ph|access-date=2016-11-20}}</ref>
In 2012, they became the country's retailer of American manufacturer of computer components, Antec.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hardwarezone.com.ph/tech-news-antec-picks-octagon-computer-superstore-official-retail-partner|title=Antec Picks Octagon Computer Superstore as Official Retail Partner|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Despite the aggressiveness of their competitors, Octagon Computer Superstore became the predominant in the computer retail industry with around 151 branches<ref name=":0" /> versus its closest rival [[Silicon Valley Computer Group Philippines]] with 51 branches<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://siliconvalley.com.ph/branches/?v=a25496ebf095|title=BRANCHES – Silicon Valley|website=siliconvalley.com.ph|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> and Gaisano Interpace Computer Systems with 20 branches.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gaisano-interpace.com/contact.htm|title=Interpace Computers|website=www.gaisano-interpace.com|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
== Branches == Octagon now has 150 branches nationwide with around 1,000 employees.<ref name=":1" /> Across the country, they are commonly seen in major malls like [[SM Supermalls|SM Malls]], [[KCC Malls]], [[Robinsons Malls|Robinson's Malls]], and [[Gaisano Malls]].<ref name=":0"/> Octagon Computer Superstore and Micro Valley Computer Center has stand-alone branches in [[Manila]], [[Zamboanga City|Zamboanga]], [[Dumaguete]], [[Vigan]], [[Batangas]], [[Butuan]], [[Cagayan de Oro|Cagayan De Oro]], [[Dipolog]] and [[Davao City|Davao]].

'''''Public Speaking and Influencing Men In Business''''' ({{ISBN|0-7661-6973-1}}) is a [[public speaking]] book written by [[Dale Carnegie]] in 1937 and first published in 1926 as ''Public Speaking: a Practical Course for Business Men'', with several revised editions published later. Dorothy Carnegie produced 2 separate revised editions: ''How to Develop Self-Confidence and Influence People by Public Speaking'' (1956), aimed at the general public, and ''The Quick and Easy Way to Effective Speaking'' (1962), as a replacement textbook for the Dale Carnegie Course. A more recent revised edition is ''Public Speaking for Success'' (2005), revised by Arthur Pell, which restores content that was left out of the Dorothy Carnegie-revised works.
''Public Speaking: a Practical Course for Business Men'', ''Public Speaking and Influencing Men In Business'', and ''The Quick and Easy Way to Effective Speaking'' served as standard textbooks in the Dale Carnegie Course.
The main focus of this book is to present a thorough understanding of the principles of public speaking, as well as guidance into conquering the fears attributed to public speaking.
==Contents== # Developing Courage and Self Confidence # Self-Confidence thru Preparation # How Famous Speakers Prepared Their Addresses # The Improvement of Memory # Keeping the Audience Awake # Essential Elements in Successful Speaking # The Secret of Good Delivery # Platform Presence and Personality # How to Open a Talk # Capturing Your Audience at Once # How to Close a Talk # How to Make your Meaning Clear # How to Be Impressive and Convincing # How to Interest your Audience # How to Get Action # Improving your Diction
Appendices: * ''[[Acres of Diamond]]'' by [[Russell Conwell]] * ''[[A Message to Garcia]]'' by [[Elbert Hubbard]] * ''[[As a Man Thinketh]]'' by [[James Allen (author)|James Allen]]

'''Shirriff''' is the brand name of several food products first produced by the defunct Shirriff family food products company in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], [[Canada]]. Francis Shirriff founded a food extracts company in the 1880s. The company would go on develop a line of food products including marmalades, dessert toppings and jelly and pudding mixes. The company remained a family business until the 1950s when it was sold to the owner of the Dominion Stores chain. Later, the firm was bought by [[Kelloggs]] of Canada. In 1988 and 1992, Kelloggs sold its interests. Many of the Shirriff brand products are still in production, although now by other companies: [[The J. M. Smucker Company]] and [[Dr. Oetker]]. The company's most well-known product was likely its "Good Morning Marmalade", the best-selling marmalade in Canada.<ref name="david-obit"/> Francis Shirriff was also one of the founders of the Niagara Falls Wine Company, later known as Bright's and Vincor International.
==History== Francis Adam Shirriff was born in [[Huntingdon, Quebec]], the son of [[Scottish people|Scottish]] emigrant doctor Francis Walker Shirriff and Anna Macnider.<ref name="nfobit"/> He moved to [[Toronto]] in 1872 at the age of 24 and began working in the grocery business.<ref name="nfobit"/> In 1874, Shirriff started the Niagara Falls Wine Company with Thomas G. Bright.<ref name="nfobit"/>
In 1883, Shirriff founded his own business, the Imperial Extract Company, which sold essential oils and flavour extracts,<ref name="david-obit"/> beginning a long career in food production. The company exhibited at the [[Canadian National Exhibition|Toronto Industrial Exhibition]] in 1885. Their exhibit was described by the ''Canadian Pharmaceutical Journal'' as "One of the handsomest exhibits" and "This firm have made a specialty of fruit and flavoring extracts, and are also giving considerable attention to perfumery, of both which they made a handsome display."<ref>{{cite journal |publisher=Canadian Pharmaceutical Association, Ontario College of Pharmacy |journal=Canadian Pharmaceutical Journal |volume=19 1885–86 |editor-first=E.B. |editor-last=Shuttleworth |year=1885 |issue=3, October 1885|p=32 |title=The Chemical Section at the Industrial Exhibition |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RWUCAAAAYAAJ& }}</ref> The company's address in the 1886 city directory was 48 Colborne Street, listed for essential oils and perfumery.<ref name=tcd1886/>The company won a Bronze Medal for their display at the 1887 show and displayed a new product of lemon juice.<ref>{{cite journal |publisher=Canadian Pharmaceutical Association, Ontario College of Pharmacy |journal=Canadian Pharmaceutical Journal |volume=21, 1887-1888 |editor-first=E.B. |editor-last=Shuttleworth |title=The Chemical Section at the Combined Dominion and Industrial Exhibition |page=30 |issue=3, October 1887 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WGMCAAAAYAAJ&}}</ref>
Bright and Shirriff moved to Niagara Falls to concentrate on the wine business,<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Brock University |title=Brock University Digital Repository |url=http://dr.library.brocku.ca/handle/10464/2683/browse?value=Niagara+Falls+Wine+Company&type=subject }}</ref> while the Imperial Extract Co. continued its operations in Toronto. In 1889, the company is listed at 49 Front Street East, sharing space with Bright, listed for essential oils, flavouring extracts, and baking powder.<ref name=tcd1889/> Shirriff's sons Colin, Francis, and William joined the business in the following decades.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=9}} The company moved to 54 Colborne, sharing space with Bright and the Niagara Falls Wine Company.<ref name=tcd1903/>
In 1903, Shiriff first made marmalade.<ref name="gm1956">{{cite news |work=The Globe and Mail |title=Food Research |date=November 19, 1956 |page=32}}</ref> In 1905, it displayed its marmalades at a booth at the Pure Food Show at [[Massey Hall]]. The ''[[Toronto Daily Star]]'' reported: "One of the most daintily dressed booths in the hall is that of Shirriffs marmalades and flavoring essence. The public is invited to sample the delicious shredded orange marmalade served with reception wafers. Numbers of people took advantage of the invitation yesterday afternoon and expressions of approval were frequent. It is absolutely pure, containing nothing but the finest fruit and granulated sugar."<ref name="star-1905">{{cite news |title=Attractive Exhibits at Pure Food Show |work=Toronto Daily Star |date=April 6, 1905 |p=4}}</ref> The company also showed its jelly powders and flavouring extracts.<ref name="star-1905"/>
By 1909, the company was prosperous enough to build its own factory at 8–12 Matilda Street at Steiner (now Carroll) Street, just north of Queen Street East in Toronto.<ref name=tcd11/> The building, designed by architect Charles Herbert Acton Bond of Bond & Smith<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dictionaryofarchitectsincanada.org/node/1669 |title=Bond, Charles Herbert Acton |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref> was built at a cost of $20,000.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=9}} The factory housed both the Shirriff production line and the Niagara Falls Wine Company.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=9}} In 1911, the Shirriffs sold their share of the Niagara Falls Wine Company. Thomas Bright also sold out in 1933.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=9}}
As a youth, naturalist [[Charles Sauriol]], worked at the Shirriff factory after school and during the summers. Sauriol wrote about his experience:
{{Quote|text=At Shirriffs I learned several things about Seville oranges, also how jelly powders were made.... We ate a lot of jelly at home in those days. Each Friday the employees were given an opportunity to buy five pound damaged tins of marmalade for bargain prices under a dollar, and many the can I brought home. The Shirriffs were very kind to me and Will the senior partner would often stop to chat with me. |source=Charles Sauriol in Toronto Archives, Charles Sauriol Fonds, Box 123286-4, Series 107, File 26<ref>{{cite book |first=Charles |last=Sauriol |title=Boyhood Memories |page=Chapter 6, p/ 2 |year=1980 }}</ref> }}
[[File:Shirriff Advertisement 1929.jpg|thumb|right|Advertisement depicting Shirriff finding source of recipe]] In the 1920s, Shirriff advertised nationally in newspapers, describing their marmalades as something traditional, artisanal, and above all genuinely Scottish.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=10}} An advertisement in the Ottawa Citizen of 1929 had the following text:
{{Quote|text=On a trip to Scotland many years ago, Francis A. Shirriff stopped at an old Scottish hostel famed for its good food. A remarkably delicious marmalade was served. Inquiring from the inn-keeper, he found it was made by a master marmalade maker whose name was known throughout all Scotland. His rare old recipe was sought by many, but its secrets were known only to himself. It was a heritage passed on from father to son. "Surely this is a treat for Canadians to enjoy" - thought Mr. Shirriff, and with that in mind he offered to purchase the recipe. A price was eventually agreed upon and the recipe became his. That is how it came to Canada. This is why you can now enjoy luscious, full flavoured marmalade, the same as was made in that quaint old Scottish shop many years ago - from that "Rare Old Scotch Recipe|source=Ottawa Citizen<ref name="cit1929">{{cite news |work=Ottawa Citizen |date=October 15, 1929 |title=Shirriff's Marmalades display ad |p=17 |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=O6guAAAAIBAJ&sjid=kNoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3867%2C2854446 }}</ref> }}
At the time, Shirriff sold three types of marmalade: Seville Orange, Shredded Orange, and Pineapple. Prices ranged from a 12 oz. jar for 25¢ to four-pounds for 55¢.<ref name="cit1929"/>
In 1927, Shirriff introduced the "Flavour Bud", a dissolvable capsule of extract for making jelly. Shiriff introduced the "Lushus" brand of products using the "Flavour Bud."<ref name="gm1956"/> In 1930, Shirriff introduced its "Good Morning" Marmalade, a recipe of three citrus fruits: oranges, grapefruit and lemons.
Francis Shirriff, Sr. died in 1944 at the age of 97.<ref name="nfobit"/> and the company passed to his sons. In 1947, his grandson William David (David), son of William, joined the company. In his youth he had worked at the company, including working in the Shirriff booth at the Canadian National Exhibition.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=10}} David fought in [[Italy]] during [[World War II]] and, in 1947, entered the family business in a managerial capacity.<ref name="david-obit"/>
By 1953, the company's 70th year, David Shirriff had risen in the business to take charge of the jam division.{{sfn|Hood|2012|p=10}} The Shirriffs decided to sell the company to J. William Horsey, president of the [[Dominion (supermarket)|Dominion]] chain of supermarkets. "His father had died and his uncles were elderly and tired of the business demands so the time seemed right to sell."<ref name="david-obit"/> Horsey asked him to stay on and manage the new company, known as Shirriff-Horsey.<ref name="david-obit"/> In 1956, the company was estimated to have one-third of the marmalade, extracts and jelly powder market in Canada.<ref name="gm1956"/>
Shirriff-Horsey was merged with [[Salada tea|Salada Tea]] in June 1957. The merger created a large multinational food company. It was described as "an international food organization manufacturing and processing a variety of products in six cities in three countries," including a plant in [[Jamaica]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Shirriff-Horsey, Salada Tea Merger Creates Huge Company |newspaper=Lakeland Ledger |date=June 30, 1957 |p=2D |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1346&dat=19570630&id=c1pYAAAAIBAJ&sjid=HPoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7100,62}}</ref> In 1958, the company acquired the "[[Junket (company)|Junket]]" dessert products company and its factory in Little Falls, New York.<ref name="junket">{{cite web |url=http://www.junketdesserts.com/history.aspx |title=History |publisher=Redco Foods |accessdate=October 22, 2016}}</ref> In 1962, the company name was changed to Salada Foods.<ref name="junket"/>
For several years, starting in the 1950s, Shirriff Salada gave away coins with depictions of [[National Hockey League]] hockey players on them in their food packages. At first, these coins were made of metal, but the company converted to plastic coins in the 1960s.<ref name="wrr">{{cite news |work=Waterloo Region Record |first=Ron |last=Stephenson |title=A piece of Leaf heaven |date=April 28, 2014 |page=A1}}</ref> These are bought and sold today as collector items.<ref name="wrr"/> The company also introduced [[hockey cards]] and baseball player [[trading cards]] in their packages.
In 1965, David Shirriff left the company, thus bringing to an end the Shirriff family's 82-year association with the company.<ref name="david-obit"/> Horsey sold the company to cereal company [[Kellogg's|Kellogg's of Canada]] in 1969.<ref name="junket"/> In 1988, Kellogg Salada sold the Shirriff ice cream toppings, jams and marmalades to the [[United States|American]] J.M. Smucker Company.<ref>{{cite news |newspaper=The Globe and Mail |first=Sandra |last=Coulson |title=Kellogg Salada is selling product brand to U.S. firm |date=January 6, 1988}}</ref> The American assets of Salada and Junket were sold to Redco Foods, Inc.<ref name="junket"/> and the Canadian assets to Unilever Ltd. In 1992, Kellogg sold the remaining Shirriff brands it owned (pie fillings and instant potatoes) to the Germany-based Dr. Oetker Ltd.<ref>{{cite news |first=Mark |last=Evans |title=Shirriff unloaded: Kellogg Canada sells food division |work=National Post |date=March 25, 1992 |p=12}}</ref>
David Shirriff entered the plastics business after leaving Salada Foods. He also bought the Crown Inn, a 1200s-era inn in [[Chiddingfold]], [[England]]. He sold the plastics business in 1992 and retired. He died in 2008 in the Veterans Section of [[Sunnybrook Hospital]] in Toronto.<ref name="david-obit"/> He was survived by Elizabeth, his wife of 60 years, their children Bill, Martha and Judy, his sister Kathryn and four grandchildren.<ref name="david-obit"/>
The Shirriff factory on Matilda Street still stands, used by other businesses. Shirriff's Good Morning Marmalade is produced by J. M. Smuckers in the United States and marketed as Shirriff's Pure Marmalade.<ref>Per product packaging.</ref> Dr. Oetker continues to make Shirriff products at its factory in [[Mississauga]], Ontario, Canada.
==Products== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * baking powder<ref name=tcd1889/> * essential oils<ref name=tcd1889/> * flavour extracts<ref name=tcd1889/> * ice cream toppings * jelly powders * marmalades * mincemeat<ref name=tcd11/> * pie fillings * pudding mixes {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist|30em|refs= <ref name="david-obit">{{cite news |first=Gay |last=Abbate |title=David Shirriff, 86: Army Officer and Businessman |work=The Globe and Mail |date=December 1, 2008 |url=http://groups.google.com/group/alt.obituaries/browse_thread/thread/3f65396e564883ca?pli=1.}}</ref> <ref name="nfobit">{{cite web |url=http://www.nflibrary.ca/nfplindex/show.asp?id=328585&b=1 |title=Dies at age 97 - Details |publisher=Niagara Falls Public Library}}</ref> <ref name=tcd1886>{{cite web |type=pdf |website=Toronto Public Library |url=http://static.torontopubliclibrary.ca/da/pdfs/1316282_3.pdf |author=R L Polk & Co |title=Toronto City Directory |year=1886 |pp=4,899,933}}</ref> <ref name=tcd1889>{{cite book |author=R L Polk & Co |title=Toronto City Directory |website=Toronto Public Library |url=http://static.torontopubliclibrary.ca/da/pdfs/tcd1889.pdf |type=pdf |year=1889 |pp=117,736}}</ref> <ref name=tcd1903>{{cite book |url=http://static.torontopubliclibrary.ca/da/pdfs/torontodirec190300mighuoft.pdf |type=pdf |title=Toronto City Directory |website=Toronto Public Library |author=Might's Directories Ltd. |year=1903 |pp=121,543}}</ref> <ref name=tcd11>{{cite book |title=Toronto City Directory |author=Might's Directories Ltd. |year=1911 |p=223 |url=http://static.torontopubliclibrary.ca/da/pdfs/31385037145404d.pdf |website=Toronto Public Library |accessdate=October 24, 2016}}</ref> }}
;References * {{cite journal |journal=Culinary Chronicles: Newsletter of the Culinary Historians of Canada |title=The Shirriff Saga: The story of a Toronto marmalade dynasty |issue=No. 70 April, 2012 |first=Sarah B. |last=Hood |year=2012 |pp=9–11 |ref=harv |url=http://culinaryhistorians.ca/wordpress/wp-content/uploads/2011/08/CHC-Culinary-Chronicles-Spring-2012-Newsletter_2.pdf |type=PDF}}

{{redirects here|Business strategy|other uses|business process}} {{Strategy}} {{Business administration}} In the field of [[management]], '''strategic management''' involves the formulation and implementation of the major [[goal]]s and initiatives taken by an [[organization]]'s top [[managers | management]] on behalf of owners, based on consideration of [[Factors of production |resources]] and an assessment of the internal and external environments in which the organization operates.{{cite journal | journal= [[Strategic Management Journal]] | year=2007 |volume=28 | issue=9 | pages=935–955 | title= What is strategic management, really? Inductive derivation of a consensus definition of the field |author1=Nag, R. |author2= Hambrick, D. C. |author3=Chen, M.-J |doi= 10.1002/smj.615 |url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/smj.615/pdf | format=PDF | accessdate=October 22, 2012}}{{qn|date=June 2018}} Compare a corporation-oriented view: {{cite book | last1 = Alkhafaji | first1 = Abbass F. | orig-year = 2003 | title = Strategic Management: Formulation, Implementation, and Control in a Dynamic Environment | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=DVfhAQAAQBAJ | location = New York | publisher = Routledge | publication-date = 2013 | page = | isbn = 9781135186357 | access-date = 2018-06-17 | quote = Strategic management is the process of assessing the corporation and its environment in order to meet the firm's long-term objectives of adapting and adjusting to its environment through manipulation of opportunities and reduction of threats. }} Compare broader definitions of strategic management encompassing the management of non-commercial entities: {{cite book | last1 = Courtney | first1 = Roger | title = Strategic Management for Voluntary Nonprofit Organizations | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=3krtbD3zKSEC | series = Routledge studies in the management of voluntary and non-profit organizations | volume = 5 | location = London | publisher = Psychology Press | publication-date = 2002 | page = 8 | isbn = 9780415250238 | access-date = 2018-06-17 | quote = [...] 'Strategic Management' as 'the process of strategic change' (Bowman and Asche 1987) or as 'the process of making and implementing strategic decisions', 'strategic decisions' being those 'that determine the overall direction of an enterprise and its ultimate viability in light of the ... changes that may occur in its ... environments' (Quinn 1980). }} Strategic management provides overall direction to an enterprise and involves specifying the organization's [[goal | objective]]s, developing [[policy | policies]] and [[plan]]s to achieve those objectives, and then allocating resources to implement the plans. Strategic management is not static in nature; the models often{{quantify|date=June 2018}} include a feedback loop to monitor execution and to inform the next round of planning. {{cite book | last1 = Hill | first1 = Charles W. This information and knowledge is returned to the corporate level through feedback loops, and becomes the input for the next round of strategy formulation and implementation. }} (Lamb, 1984:ix)Lamb, Robert, Boyden ''Competitive strategic management'', Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice-Hall, 1984 [[Michael Porter]] identifies three principles underlying strategy:{{cite journal |journal= [[Harvard Business Review]] |year=1996 |issue=November–December 1996 |title= What is Strategy? |author= Porter, Michael E.}} * creating a "[[uniqueness|unique]] and valuable [market] position" * making trade-offs by choosing "what not to do" * creating "fit" by aligning company activities with one another to support the chosen strategy '''Corporate strategy''' involves answering a key question from a portfolio perspective: "What business should we be in?" '''Business strategy''' involves answering the question: "How shall we compete in this business?"Chaffee, E. "Three models of strategy", ''Academy of Management Review'', vol 10, no. 1, 1985.
